1. **Automatically enable S3 Block Public Access and disable S3 ACLs for all new S3 buckets:** Enforce new default bucket security settings. SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2023/04/amazon-s3-security-best-practices-buckets-default/

2. **Use S3 Object Lambda and Amazon Comprehend together:** Enhance the security of sensitive data by redacting and transforming personally identifiable information (PII). SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/strengthen-the-security-of-sensitive-data-stored-in-amazon-s3-by-using-additional-aws-services/

3. **Implement a broad set of security controls for S3:** Follow Amazon S3 security, access management, encryption, and data protection best practices. SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/s3/security/

4. **Protect Data from Accidental Deletion:** Utilize S3 Versioning and S3 Object Lock. SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/top-10-security-best-practices-for-securing-data-in-amazon-s3/

5. **Enable block public access settings for S3 buckets:** Prevent unauthorized public access. SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/access-control-block-public-access.html

6. **Enable logging for S3 buckets:** Log all access requests for auditing. SOURCE: CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark

7. **Enforce encryption in transit:** Use HTTPS to secure data in transit to and from S3. SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingSSL.html

8. **Enable versioning on S3 buckets:** Preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object. SOURCE: NIST Special Publication 800-53

9. **Implement MFA Delete:** Require multi-factor authentication for object deletion or versioning suspension. SOURCE: CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark

10. **Use IAM roles and policies for S3 access control:** Minimize permissions and enforce least privilege. SOURCE: NIST Special Publication 800-53

11. **Enable Amazon S3 Default Encryption:** Automatically encrypt S3 objects when stored. SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/bucket-encryption.html

12. **Implement data classification:** Apply classification labels and enforce access based on classification levels. SOURCE: STIGs

13. **Restrict S3 bucket access to specific IP addresses:** Use bucket policies to whitelist IP addresses. SOURCE: CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark

14. **Regularly review S3 bucket permissions:** Periodically audit ACLs and policy permissions. SOURCE: NIST Special Publication 800-53

1. **Enable block public access settings for S3 buckets (AWS Security Best Practices):** Prevent unauthorized public access to S3 buckets. Source: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/access-control-block-public-access.html

2. **Enable logging for S3 buckets (CIS AWS Foundations):** Log all access requests to S3 buckets for auditing. Source: https://d0.awsstatic.com/whitepapers/compliance/AWS_CIS_Foundations_Benchmark.pdf

3. **Enforce encryption in transit (AWS Security Best Practices):** Use HTTPS to secure data in transit to and from S3. Source: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingSSL.html

4. **Enable versioning on S3 buckets (NIST Special Publication 800-53):** Preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in S3 buckets. Source: https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-53r5.pdf

5. **Implement MFA Delete (CIS AWS Foundations):** Require multi-factor authentication to permanently delete an object version or suspend versioning on S3 buckets. Source: https://d0.awsstatic.com/whitepapers/compliance/AWS_CIS_Foundations_Benchmark.pdf

6. **Use IAM roles and policies for S3 access control (NIST Special Publication 800-53):** Minimize permissions and enforce least privilege through IAM roles and policies for accessing S3 resources. Source: https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-53r5.pdf

7. **Enable Amazon S3 Default Encryption (AWS Security Best Practices):** Automatically encrypt S3 objects when stored. Source: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/bucket-encryption.html

8. **Implement data classification (STIGs):** Apply classification labels to data stored in S3 and enforce access based on classification levels. Source: https://public.cyber.mil/stigs/

9. **Restrict S3 bucket access to specific IP addresses (CIS AWS Foundations):** Use S3 bucket policies to whitelist IP addresses that can access the S3 resources. Source: https://d0.awsstatic.com/whitepapers/compliance/AWS_CIS_Foundations_Benchmark.pdf

10. **Regularly review S3 bucket permissions (NIST Special Publication 800-53):** Periodically audit S3 bucket ACLs and policy permissions to ensure they follow the principle of least privilege. Source: https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-53r5.pdf

These controls draw from a diverse set of security guidelines and best practices provided by AWS, CIS, NIST, and STIGs, aiming to secure Amazon S3 resources effectively.

The security recommendations for Amazon S3 contained in the attached file "Trend Micro S3 - AWS S3 Best Practices" are:

1. **Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have block public access settings configured:** Enforcing that Amazon S3 buckets have block public access (BPA) settings at the bucket level.

2. **Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have server access logging configured:** Server access logging for Amazon S3 buckets should be enabled for audit and monitoring.

3. **Require an Amazon S3 buckets to have versioning configured and a lifecycle policy:** Ensuring that versioning and lifecycle policies are set for S3 buckets.

4. **Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have event notifications configured:** Setting up event notifications in Amazon S3 buckets for real-time alerts on specified bucket events.

5. **Require that an Amazon S3 bucket does not manage user access with an access control list (ACL):** Advising against the use of ACLs for managing user access to S3 buckets.

6. **Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have lifecycle policies configured:** Insisting on having lifecycle policies for S3 buckets.

7. **Require that Amazon S3 bucket requests use Secure Socket Layer:** Enforcing the use of SSL for requests to Amazon S3 buckets.

8. **Require that an Amazon S3 bucket has S3 Object Lock activated:** Activating S3 Object Lock for the protection against object deletion or modification.

9. **Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have server-side encryption configured using an AWS KMS key:** Mandating server-side encryption with AWS KMS keys for S3 buckets.

10. **Require an Amazon S3 bucket to have versioning enabled:** Enforcing the use of versioning in S3 buckets.

11. **Require an Amazon S3 access point to have a Block Public Access (BPA) configuration with all options set to true:** Enforcing that Amazon S3 access points have BPA settings with all options enabled.

The "Top 10 Security Best Practices for Securing Data in Amazon S3" page provides several key security recommendations for Amazon S3 users:

1. **Protect Data from Accidental Deletion:** Utilize S3 Versioning and S3 Object Lock to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your buckets. This is crucial for protecting buckets and objects from accidental deletion.

2. **Ensure Durability and Availability:** Amazon S3 is designed for a durability of 99.999999999 percent of objects across multiple Availability Zones, ensuring resilience against events that impact an entire zone. It is also designed for 99.99 percent availability over a given year.

3. **Use Bucket Policies for Specific Access Verification:** Verify that the access granted in the Amazon S3 bucket policy is restricted to specific AWS principals, federated users, service principals, IP addresses, or VPCs that you provide.

4. **Leverage AWS Services for Organization-wide Preventative Controls:** Review the latest S3 features and Amazon Web Services (AWS) services that can help secure your data in S3. This includes using organization-wide preventative controls such as AWS Organizations service control policies (SCPs).

These practices are aimed at ensuring the security of data stored in Amazon S3, highlighting the importance of utilizing AWS's built-in features and services for data protection, access control, and overall data security.

Source: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/top-10-security-best-practices-for-securing-data-in-amazon-s3/

The "AWS S3 Security Overview" page contains several security recommendations for Amazon S3:

1. **Utilize AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM):** Create users and manage their respective access permissions to Amazon S3 resources.

2. **Employ Access Control Lists (ACLs):** Make individual objects accessible to authorized users by setting up ACLs.

3. **Implement Bucket Policies:** Configure permissions for all objects within a single S3 bucket using bucket policies to manage access more granularly.

4. **Utilize Query String Authentication:** Grant time-limited access to your S3 resources with temporary URLs through Query String Authentication.

5. **Apply S3 Block Public Access:** With just a few clicks in the S3 management console, you can ensure that there is no public access to any object by applying S3 Block Public Access to every bucket in your account, including existing and any new buckets created in the future.

6. **Trusted Advisor Checks:** Leverage AWS Trusted Advisor for S3-related checks including logging configuration for Amazon S3 buckets, security checks for Amazon S3 buckets with open access permissions, and fault tolerance checks for Amazon S3 buckets that don't have versioning enabled or have it suspended.

7. **Secure Data from Unauthorized Access:** Amazon S3 provides unmatched security, compliance, and audit capabilities to help you store your data securely and manage it from unauthorized access using encryption features and access management tools.

These recommendations cover the key aspects of securing Amazon S3 resources, including managing access, applying security best practices, and utilizing built-in AWS services to enhance the security of stored data.

Source: https://aws.amazon.com/s3/security/

The security recommendations related to Amazon S3 mentioned in the webpage "Strengthen the Security of Sensitive Data Stored in Amazon S3 by Using Additional AWS Services" include:

1. Utilization of **S3 Object Lambda** and **Amazon Comprehend** together to redact and transform personally identifiable information (PII) directly from the S3 Management Console. This can be achieved by creating an S3 Object Lambda Access Point, selecting an AWS-built Lambda function, or invoking a custom Lambda function in your account.
   
2. Using **IAM Access Analyzer** for validating access to your S3 buckets before deploying permissions changes. IAM Access Analyzer helps in monitoring and reducing access by using automated reasoning to generate comprehensive findings for resource access, including the validation of whether an S3 bucket would allow public access.

3. Implementation of **GuardDuty** for monitoring and remediating configuration changes to prevent unauthorized access to Amazon S3. GuardDuty performs continuous monitoring to protect your AWS accounts and workloads, providing findings on potential security threats.

4. Configuration management with **AWS Config** to monitor and remediate configuration changes in Amazon S3, ensuring that the configurations comply with your organization's security guidelines.

5. Adoption of **S3 Object Lambda Access Points** for presenting multiple views of your data across multiple data consumers and applications. This is particularly useful for dynamic data transformation and retrieval needs.

Learning and leveraging AWS offerings to audit and secure your storage environment, including watching demos on how to configure PII redaction using S3 Object Lambda Access Points and following step-by-step instructions on implementing Amazon S3 Object Lambda to process and modify data retrieved from Amazon S3.

Overall, these recommendations focus on enhancing the security of sensitive data stored in Amazon S3 by leveraging additional AWS services for data redaction, access control, monitoring, and configuration management.
